Emergency Action Plan (19 CCR §2765.1)
Ripon Energy has a comprehensive and well developed Emergency Action Plan.
For responses beyond plant personnel capabilities, Ripon Energy relies on the Ripon Fire District (RFD), with which it has a continuous working relationship.  Per communication from the RFD, phone call to 911 is the stated method by which the RFD is to be alerted to an incident requiring Emergency Response.

Training (19 CCR §2760.4)
Ripon Energy provides documented initial and refresher training for employees conducting activities involved in the maintenance and operation of the covered process - and consults with employees about the frequency of training.

Record Keeping (19 CCR §2775.1)
Ripon Energy maintains RMP implementation records for 5 years.

Process Safety Management (8 CCR §5189.1) & Process Safety Information (19 CCR §2760.1)

Ripon Energy's Covered Process is subject to the Cal OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) requirements per the regulatory reference below.
Process Safety Information (PSI) is a fundamental component of PSM.

Ripon Energy's PSM includes all of the Program 3 elements presented in this document, such as various safety procedures, operating procedures, maintenance procedures, and PSI.

Ripon Energy's PSI includes Operating Procedures, P&IDs, MOC and PSSR practices, MI practices, audits, audits/inspections and associated findings, forms, Regulated Substance Information, Technology Information (19 CCR §2760.1(c)), Block Flow Diagram or Simplified Process Flow Diagram (8 CCR §5189(d)(2)(a)), Process Chemistry (8 CCR §5189(d)(2)(b)), Maximum Intended Inventory (8 CCR §5189(d)(2)(c)), Safe Upper and Lower Limits (8 CCR §5189(d)(2)(d)), Consequences of Deviations (8 CCR §5189(d)(2)(e)), Materials of Construction (8 CCR §5189(d)(3)(a)(1)), Electrical Classification (8 CCR §5189(d)(3)(a)(3)), Pressure Safety Relief System Design and Design Basis (8 C

agement Plan, Emergency Action Plan, Lockout and Tagout, Fire Prevention Plan, Confined Space and Enclosed Space Entry, Hazardous Material Communication Program, Electrical Safety, Welding and Cutting, Work Permits, Contractor Safety, and Hot Work.

Mechanical Integrity (19 CCR §2760.5)
Ripon Energy maintains a mechanical integrity (MI) practices to ensure continued integrity of the covered processes equipment by maintaining, inspecting and testing equipment consistent with manufacturers' recommendations and good engineering practices.  The mechanical integrity practices include inventory of process equipment; process and instrumentation diagrams; maintenance, inspection, and testing schedules; maintenance documentation, 

Management of Change (MOC) (19 CCR §2760.6) and Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR) (19 CCR §2760.7)
Ripon Energy uses MOC and PSSR to safely and efficiently manage changes to the covered processes.

Compliance Audits (19 CCR §2760.8)
Ripon Energy conducts audits for compliance with EPA RMP, CalARP, and California Process Safety Management Standard requirements at least once every three years.  The most recent three-year Compliance Audit was completed in November, 2104.

Incident Investigation (19 CCR §2760.9)
Ripon Energy investigates all incidents and accidents, including near-miss incidents and does so in compliance with the applicable regulation.

Employee Participation (19 CCR §2760.10)
Ripon Energy solicits and (in some cases) requires the participation of employees (and where applicable, their representatives) in the advancement of the RMP program.  At least one employee has direct involvement in the PHA process.  
Ripon Energy employees (and where applicable, their representatives) have access to all CalARP/RMP documentation.

Hot Work Permits (19 CCR §2760.11)
Ripon Energy has a comprehensive and well developed work permit program, which includes Hot Work Permits.

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY (19 CCR §2745.3)

Certification (19 CCR §2745.2. §2745.9)
The CalARP / RMP Program is certified by an informed and qualified individual to be true in its content and implemented to the best of the facility's capabilities.

Risk Management Plan Overview
Ripon Energy owns and operates an electricity generation facility (facility) at 944 South Stockton Ave., Ripon, CA in San Joaquin County, California, in an area of primarily light industrial use.

The facility has one chemical in one process as defined in the regulations that is regulated under the California Accidental Release Prevention Program (CalARP) (Title 19, California Code of Regulations [CCR], Chapter 4.5).  
Ripon Energy's Ammonia System uses Refrigeration Grade (99+percent) anhydrous ammonia (CAS No. 7664 41 7) (1) as the refrigerant in a combustion-air precooler and (2) as a reactant for NOx emissions reduction in a Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) system

General Requirements
Ripon Energy's CalARP / RMP is RMP Program Level 3 (19 CCR §2735.4).
Ripon Energy maintains a Management System (19 CCR §2735.6) that assigns responsibilities and resources for implementing EPA and CalARP/RMP provisions.  

EPA RMP Registration Information (19 CCR §2740.1) is included in the Program.
Ripon Energy submits to EPA (19 CCR §2745.1) (19 CCR §2735.5) via RMP E SUBMIT and to the SJC EHD (Administering Agency, AA) as required.
Ripon Energy updates (19 CCR §2745.10) and corrects (19 CCR §2745.10.5) the RMP per regulation.  Ripon Energy also follows the regulation for Covered Process Modifications (19 CCR §2745.11).

Hazard Assessment
Ripon Energy performs Hazard Assessment (19 CCR §2750.1) worst-case and alternate worst-case release scenario analyses, Offsite Consequence Analysis (OCA) (19 CCR §2750.2) per RMP EPA OCA Guidance.
The Worst-Case Release Scenario Analysis (19 CCR §2750.3) considers the release of the total quantity of anhydrous ammonia contained in the Ammonia Storage Ta

nk under poorest possible atmospheric conditions.
The Alternate Worst-Case Release Scenario Analysis (19 CCR §2750.4) considers an equally massive release under better atmospheric conditions.
The analyses provide definition of Offsite Impacts to the Population (19 CCR §2750.5) and Offsite Impacts to the Environment (19 CCR §2750.6), including distances to Toxic Endpoints.

OCA Review and Updates the OCA at least once every five years or more frequently as defined the regulation (19 CCR §2750.7).  
Five-Year Accident History

Ripon Energy presents a Five-Year Accident History (19 CCR §2750.9) in the Program Document, inclusive of accidental releases on November 16, 2011 and on August 29, 2013.
The information summarized includes the initiating events, the onsite impacts, the offsite impacts, the offsite response, and corrective measures.

Ripon Energy's Level 3 Prevention Program

Ripon Energy is has developed and implemented a Prevention Program consistent with Level 3 requirements.  The Prevention Program includes:

Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) (19 CCR §2760.2)
Ripon Energy conducts Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) at least every five years to identify, evaluate, and control the risk associated with process hazards or chemical release scenarios involving the covered processes.  The most recent PHA utilized a what-if analysis and was completed in November 2012.  Action Items are tracked to completion in Program documents.

Operating Procedures (19 CCR §2760.3)
Ripon Energy maintains written procedures to operate the covered processes that include operating limits, safety and health considerations, and safety systems functionality.  Applicable Operating Procedures are reviewed, updated, and certified annually or when changes are made to the Ammonia System.  Revisions are documented in the revision history of the procedure.
